pr_title: [BEAM-10137] Add KinesisIO for cross-language usage with python wrapper

timeline.message: [BEAM-10137] Add KinesisIO Read Cross-language transform
[BEAM-10137] Add KinesisIO Read Cross-language transform
[BEAM-10137] Add KinesisIO Read Cross-language transform
[BEAM-10137] Add KinesisIO Read Cross-language transform

timeline.bodyText: I think it would be cleaner just to have a single registrar with inner classes for all the builders and the configuration classes. WDYT?
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

replies.bodyText: I much prefer extracting as much code as possible but since everything is in one package in Kinesis then it makes sense. I'll do this change in Write PR. To be honest I'm not sure whether splitting this to 4PRs is a good idea, but I'll give it a try
replies.author: piotr-szuberski

replies.bodyText: Yeah I think I would actually prefer reviewing it as one big PR if that's ok with you
replies.author: TheNeuralBit

timeline.bodyText: We should file a jira for making KinesisIO.Read (with metadata) available. I think this would be possible if we register a schema for KinesisRecord, but it won't work cross-language until we have portable support for datetimes (i.e. BEAM-7554 will be a blocker). Also maybe this one should use a URN like "read_without_metadata" or "read_data_only" so we can use "read" in the future.
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

replies.bodyText: Also bikesheddy comment: I'm not sure about the name TypedWithoutMetadata, should it be ReadWithoutMetadata?
replies.author: TheNeuralBit

replies.bodyText: My first attempt was to register a KnownCoder with coder registrar for KinesisRecord, but later I noticed that datetime is missing so I tried to send longs. But even so I still was getting beam:coders:javasdk:0.1 when I tried to use it in python.
replies.author: piotr-szuberski

replies.bodyText: I followed the code in KafkaIO where TypedWithoutMetadata is used. ReadWithoutMetadata tells indeed much more.
replies.author: piotr-szuberski

replies.bodyText: I changed the URN to read_data, I think it's self-explanatory for a kinesis user.
replies.author: piotr-szuberski

timeline.bodyText:
I think it will be confusing to have this function here, since every other with... method returns a Read class. A user might expect to be able to do:
KinesisIO.read()
   .withoutMetadata()
   .withMaxCapacityPerShard(x)

Instead we should add a KinesisIO.readWithoutMetadata() that returns something like TypedWithoutMetadata with all the same configuration parameters as Read. You might take a look at how this is handled in PubsubIO for inspiration, I think it has a similar problem where it supports multiple different output types, but we want them all to share some configuration parameters. It looks like the way it's handled there is with a Read type, and you pass in a function for converting PubsubMessage to T.
Alternatively, you could move the logic to extract the payload into the external transform builder, rather than adding the interface here (I think there's value in adding it here though if you want to take it on).
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

replies.bodyText: Thanks for pointing it, I followed the KafkaIO convention and didn't think whether it's a good design or not. The change is trivial, just use KinesisIO.readWithoutMetadata() and pass Read there instead of creating it in withoutMetadata(this).
replies.author: piotr-szuberski

replies.bodyText: Thanks for pointing it out. Done.

timeline.bodyText:
@lukecwik I suggested that Piotr make Read generic so that we can add Read<byte[]> readData() naturally, but now I'm wondering if this is a bad idea since it changes our Public API. Does this have a risk of breaking users?
It looks like at least the way the method is used in our tests (p.apply(KinesisIO.read())) is unaffected.
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

replies.bodyText: Prob. this is OK as long as the change is backwards compatible for user pipelines.
replies.author: chamikaramj

replies.bodyText:
The worst thing I can imagine is that a user will get a raw type warning if he used it like KinesisIO.Read read = KinesisIO.read();. Some users could have some checkers that would turn it into an error though. I don't know how much common such tools are in the Java development in projects using Beam.
PCollection<KinesisRecord> = pipeline.apply(KinesisIO.read()...)); doesn't change so I think it's ok.
replies.author: piotr-szuberski

replies.bodyText: I think it should be fine if it doesn't require a user code change.
replies.author: aromanenko-dev

timeline.bodyText: We should prefer the checker framework Nullable annotation, org.checkerframework.checker.nullness.qual.Nullable
